name: Barbell Back Squat High Bar
description: The foundational compound lower body exercise with the barbell positioned on the upper traps, promoting a more upright torso and greater quad emphasis. This Olympic-style squat allows for deep knee flexion and is essential for building overall leg strength and mass.
instructions: Position barbell on upper traps, grip bar wider than shoulders with elbows down
Unrack bar, step back and set feet shoulder-width apart, toes slightly out
Brace core, initiate descent by breaking at hips and knees simultaneously
Descend until hip crease is below knee level, keeping torso upright
Drive through feet to stand, extending hips and knees together
formCues: Full depth - hip crease below knee

name: Barbell Back Squat Low Bar
description: A powerlifting-style squat variation with the barbell positioned lower on the rear deltoids, creating greater forward lean and posterior chain engagement. This position typically allows for heavier loads and emphasizes hip drive.
instructions: Position barbell across rear deltoids below the spine of scapula
Grip bar with narrower grip, wrists straight, elbows up and back
Unrack and set feet slightly wider than shoulder width
Initiate by pushing hips back, then bend knees
Descend to parallel or below, drive hips forward to ascend
formCues: Bar sits on rear delts, not traps
More hip hinge than high bar

name: Front Squat
description: An advanced squat variation with the barbell resting on the front deltoids and clavicles, requiring exceptional mobility and core strength. The front-loaded position forces a more upright torso, maximizing quadriceps engagement.
instructions: Position barbell on front deltoids with clean grip or crossed-arm grip
Keep elbows high, upper arms parallel to floor throughout
Set feet shoulder-width apart, toes slightly out
Descend by breaking at knees and hips, keeping torso vertical
Drive through heels to stand, maintaining high elbow position
formCues: Elbows HIGH - upper arms parallel to floor

name: Goblet Squat
description: A beginner-friendly squat variation holding a dumbbell or kettlebell at chest level that naturally promotes proper squat mechanics and an upright torso. The front-loaded weight serves as a counterbalance and teaches ideal squat patterning.
instructions: Hold dumbbell vertically at chest, cupping one end with both hands
Set feet shoulder-width apart, toes pointed slightly outward
Push hips back and bend knees to descend into squat
Keep chest up, elbows inside knees at bottom position
Drive through whole foot to return to standing
formCues: Elbows push knees out at bottom

name: Dumbbell Squat
description: A squat variation holding dumbbells at the sides or on the shoulders, providing a versatile option when barbells are unavailable. The independent weights challenge stability and allow for natural arm positioning.
instructions: Hold dumbbells at sides with neutral grip or on shoulders
Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, toes slightly out
Brace core and initiate descent by pushing hips back
Lower until thighs are parallel or below, keeping chest up
Drive through heels to return to standing position

name: Zercher Squat
description: An unconventional squat variation with the barbell held in the crooks of the elbows, creating extreme core and upper back demands. Named after strongman Ed Zercher, this movement builds functional strength and brutal mental toughness.
instructions: Position barbell in the crook of bent elbows, hands clasped together
Stand with feet slightly wider than shoulder width
Brace core hard, keep upper back tight
Squat down keeping elbows inside knees if possible
Drive up through legs while maintaining bar position

name: Box Squat
description: A squat variation where you descend to sit briefly on a box before standing, breaking the eccentric-concentric chain. This technique builds explosive strength from a dead stop and teaches proper depth consistency.
instructions: Set up box at height where thighs are parallel at seated position
Position barbell on upper back as for back squat
Set feet wider than normal squat stance
Descend by pushing hips back to sit on box
Pause briefly on box, then drive explosively to standing

name: Pause Squat
description: A squat variation with a deliberate pause at the bottom position, eliminating the stretch reflex and building strength out of the hole. This technique develops positional strength, control, and confidence at the most challenging part of the lift.
instructions: Set up as for standard back squat with chosen bar position
Descend under control to full depth
Hold motionless at bottom for 2-3 seconds while maintaining tension
Drive up explosively without any bounce
Complete lockout at top before next rep
formCues: Full stop at bottom - no bouncing
Use lighter weight than regular squat

name: Bodyweight Squat
description: The foundational squat pattern performed without external load, essential for learning proper mechanics before adding weight. This accessible movement builds baseline leg strength and is perfect for warm-ups, conditioning, or high-rep training.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, toes slightly pointed out
Extend arms forward for balance or place hands behind head
Initiate by pushing hips back and bending knees
Descend until thighs are parallel or below, keeping chest up
Drive through whole foot to return to standing

name: Wall Sit
description: An isometric hold with back against a wall and thighs parallel to the ground, creating sustained quadriceps tension without movement. This exercise builds muscular endurance and mental toughness while being easy to perform anywhere.
instructions: Stand with back flat against wall, feet shoulder-width apart
Slide down wall until thighs are parallel to floor
Keep knees at 90 degrees, directly over ankles
Press back firmly against wall, arms at sides or crossed
Hold position for target duration, maintaining form

name: Pistol Squat
description: An advanced single-leg squat performed with the non-working leg extended forward, requiring exceptional strength, balance, and mobility. This challenging movement demonstrates unilateral leg strength and is a pinnacle calisthenics achievement.
instructions: Stand on one leg, extend other leg straight forward
Extend arms forward for counterbalance
Descend slowly on standing leg, keeping extended leg off ground
Lower until hamstring touches calf, maintaining balance
Drive through standing foot to return to start

name: Sissy Squat
description: A quad-isolation movement where you lean backward while squatting on the balls of your feet, creating intense rectus femoris stretch and contraction. Despite its name, this challenging exercise delivers extreme quad isolation.
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width, hold something for balance if needed
Rise onto balls of feet, begin leaning torso backward
Bend knees and lower hips while leaning back further
Descend until knees are deeply flexed and quads stretched
Drive through balls of feet to return to standing
commonMistakes: Hips sitting back like normal squat

name: Hack Squat Machine
description: A machine-based squat variation with back supported against an angled pad, allowing heavy quad loading without spinal compression. The fixed path isolates the legs while providing safety for pushing to failure.
instructions: Position back flat against pad, shoulders under shoulder pads
Place feet shoulder-width on platform, toes slightly out
Release safety handles, lower by bending knees
Descend until thighs are at least parallel
Drive through feet to extend legs, don't lock out completely
formCues: Don't lock out knees at top

name: Forward Lunge
description: A fundamental unilateral movement stepping forward into a lunge position, targeting quads and glutes while challenging balance and coordination. The deceleration component makes this variation more quad-dominant.
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, hands on hips or at sides
Step forward with one leg, landing heel first
Lower hips until both knees are at approximately 90 degrees
Keep front knee over ankle, back knee hovering above floor
Push through front foot to return to starting position

name: Reverse Lunge
description: A lunge variation stepping backward that is generally more knee-friendly than forward lunges due to reduced deceleration forces. This movement allows better balance control and emphasizes the glutes slightly more.
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart
Step backward with one leg into a lunge position
Lower hips until front thigh is parallel to floor
Keep front knee over ankle, back knee hovering above ground
Drive through front heel to return to start, repeat or alternate
formCues: Push through front heel to return

name: Walking Lunge
description: A dynamic lunge variation performed in continuous forward motion, combining unilateral leg strength with cardiovascular endurance. Each step transitions directly into the next lunge, creating a demanding full-leg workout.
instructions: Stand tall with feet together, dumbbells at sides or barbell on back
Step forward into a lunge, lowering until both knees at 90 degrees
Push through front foot and bring back leg forward into next lunge
Continue walking forward, alternating legs with each step
Maintain upright posture throughout the movement

name: Bulgarian Split Squat
description: An advanced single-leg squat with the rear foot elevated on a bench, creating intense unilateral quad and glute activation. This movement addresses strength imbalances and builds stability while allowing significant loading.
instructions: Stand facing away from bench, place rear foot on bench behind you
Hop front foot forward until comfortable split stance achieved
Hold dumbbells at sides or barbell on back
Lower by bending front knee until thigh is parallel or below
Drive through front foot to return to start, complete all reps then switch
formCues: Vertical shin is optional not required
commonMistakes: Front foot too close to bench
Back foot doing too much work

name: Deficit Lunge
description: A lunge variation performed with the front foot elevated on a platform, increasing range of motion and quad stretch at the bottom. This added depth creates greater muscle tension and growth stimulus.
instructions: Stand on platform or plate 2-4 inches high
Step back with one foot into reverse lunge position
Lower hips until front thigh is well below parallel
Allow deeper stretch than standard lunge depth
Drive through elevated front foot to return to start

name: Lateral Lunge
description: A side-stepping lunge targeting the quads and adductors in the frontal plane, building lateral strength and mobility often neglected in traditional training. This movement improves hip mobility and inner thigh flexibility.
instructions: Stand with feet together, hands at chest or sides
Step wide to one side, pushing hips back
Bend stepping leg while keeping other leg straight
Lower until stepping thigh is parallel to floor
Push through stepping foot to return to center

name: Curtsy Lunge
description: A lunge variation stepping diagonally behind the body in a curtsy motion, uniquely targeting the gluteus medius and outer hip. This rotational element challenges stability and hits the glutes from a different angle.
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart
Step one leg diagonally behind and across the other
Lower hips until front thigh is parallel to floor
Keep torso upright, hips facing forward
Push through front foot to return, alternate or complete one side
formCues: Cross behind not just to side

name: Jump Lunge
description: An explosive plyometric lunge alternating legs in mid-air, developing power, coordination, and cardiovascular conditioning. This high-intensity movement builds reactive strength and athletic explosiveness.
instructions: Start in lunge position with one foot forward
Lower into lunge, loading the legs
Explode upward, switching legs in mid-air
Land softly in lunge position with opposite leg forward
Immediately descend and repeat, alternating legs

name: Step-Up
description: A unilateral exercise stepping onto an elevated surface, closely mimicking daily activities like climbing stairs. This functional movement builds single-leg strength and addresses imbalances between legs.
instructions: Stand facing a box or bench at knee height or lower
Place one foot fully on the box
Drive through the top foot to step up completely
Bring trailing leg up to meet working leg
Step down with control, complete all reps then switch

name: Box Step-Up
description: A step-up variation using a higher box that increases range of motion and demands greater single-leg strength. The elevated height creates more quad and glute engagement than standard step-ups.
instructions: Stand facing box at mid-thigh to hip height
Place one foot fully on top of box
Drive through top leg to stand completely on box
Bring trailing leg up or immediately step back down
Lower with control, complete all reps then switch legs
formCues: Start with lower box if needed

name: Leg Press
description: A machine-based compound movement allowing heavy quad and glute loading without spinal compression. The fixed path and back support make this ideal for high-volume leg training and safely pushing to failure.
instructions: Sit in leg press with back flat against pad
Place feet shoulder-width on platform, toes slightly out
Release safety locks, lower weight by bending knees
Descend until knees reach 90 degrees or comfortable depth
Drive through whole foot to extend legs, don't lock out

name: Leg Extension
description: An isolation exercise targeting the quadriceps through knee extension against resistance. This machine movement isolates the quads completely, making it ideal for pre-exhaust, pump work, or rehabilitation.
instructions: Sit in machine with back against pad, knees at edge of seat
Position ankle pad just above feet
Grip handles at sides for stability
Extend legs until straight, squeezing quads hard
Lower under control, maintaining tension throughout

name: Smith Machine Squat
description: A squat performed on a Smith machine with the barbell fixed to vertical guide rails, providing stability and safety. While less functional than free-weight squats, it allows for various foot positions and safe training to failure.
instructions: Position bar at shoulder height, step under and unrack
Set feet forward of bar path, shoulder-width apart
Unrack by rotating hooks, brace core
Lower by bending knees and hips to parallel or below
Drive through feet to stand, maintaining upright torso

name: Pendulum Squat
description: A unique machine squat where the platform swings in an arc rather than linear path, creating constant quad tension throughout the movement. The biomechanics closely match free squatting while offering machine safety.
instructions: Position shoulders under pads, feet on platform
Set foot position based on desired emphasis
Release handles, lower by bending knees
Descend to full depth following platform's arc
Drive through feet to return, maintaining tension

name: Belt Squat
description: A squat variation with load suspended from a hip belt rather than on the shoulders, completely eliminating spinal compression. This allows for heavy leg training without back stress, ideal for recovery or back issues.
instructions: Attach belt around hips, connect to weight stack or plates
Stand on platform with feet shoulder-width apart
Brace core, initiate squat by pushing hips back
Descend to full depth, keeping torso naturally upright
Drive through heels to stand, squeezing glutes at top
formCues: Squat naturally - no bar to balance
Arms free for balance or handles

name: Single-Leg Press
description: A unilateral leg press performed one leg at a time to address strength imbalances and increase range of motion. The single-leg approach ensures each leg works independently without compensation.
instructions: Sit in leg press machine with back flat against pad
Place one foot in center of platform, other foot resting off
Release safety, lower weight by bending working knee
Descend to 90 degrees or comfortable depth
Drive through foot to extend, complete all reps then switch
commonMistakes: Using much less than half weight

name: Bodyweight Leg Extension
description: A quad isolation exercise performed without machines by sitting on a surface and extending the leg against gravity or resistance. This accessible movement can be performed anywhere for quad activation.
instructions: Sit on elevated surface with knees bent at 90 degrees
Keep back straight, hands gripping surface for stability
Extend one or both legs until straight, squeezing quads
Hold contraction briefly at top
Lower under control to starting position
